I am a scientist, statistician, ecologist, modeller, and lecturer. I am based in Auckland, New Zealand, on the beautiful Hibiscus Coast.




BSc in Zoology from the University of Canterbury
P.G.Dip.Sci in Ecology from the University of Canterbury
MSc in Statistics with First Class Honours from the University of Auckland
PhD in Statistics from Massey University




I have over 20 years experience as a scientist, having worked at the Department of Conservation (DOC), the National Institute for Water and Atmospheric Research (NIWA), and for over ten years as a Lecturer/Senior Lecturer in Statistics at Massey University Auckland. I have been a Workshop Instructor/Research Associate for PRIMER-e since 2017.

title: Monitoring of blue cod in Fiordland withstereo Baited Remote Underwater Video (BRUV)
text:
Advantages of BRUVs



Cost-effective
Rapid replication
Non-destructive, non-lethal
Globally established methodology
Standardised observation period (60 min)
Broad depth range
Captures information on multiple species, size-classes, habitats
Permanent video archive





Photo credit: C. Rob Priester

title: Monitoring of blue cod in Fiordland withstereo Baited Remote Underwater Video (BRUV)
text:
Disadvantages of BRUVs





Photo credit: C. Rob Priester




Expensive upfront costs of gear
Time-consuming annotation of videos(though AI will help!)
Unknown ‘catchment’ area of bait plume
Some deployments fail
Cannot tell the sex of non-sexually dimorphic species (e.g., blue cod)




Annotation is the process of watching the videos and recording data on abundance, length, habitat, etc. We don’t call this ‘analysis’ so as not to confuse it with statistical analysis of the data.

title: Monitoring of blue cod in Fiordland withstereo Baited Remote Underwater Video (BRUV)
text:
Blue cod
Growing concern about the blue cod populations in Fiordland
Blue cod in Fiordland were historically assessed by potting surveys
No formal survey since 2014

Fiordland’s lobster fishery is a great success story, but there are growing concerns about the blue cod populations, due to increases in recreational fishing pressure.
Historically, for fishery-independent surveys, blue cod are assessed surveyed by potting. These potting surveys are quite expensive and incur a high degree of additional mortality to the stock.
The last potting survey of blue cod in Fiordland was a decade ago.

Sea Through Science is a boutique scientific consulting company, specialising in statistical analysis and modelling, data science, and education. We do much of our work in the life sciences but we work in any field or discipline. We also conduct field surveys of marine ecosystems using cutting-edge underwater video technology.
Please drop us a line to discuss potential projects or get in touch for any other reason.

title: Baited Remote Underwater Video
text:
Baited Remote Underwater Video, or BRUV, is considered the standard method for surveying fishes and habitats worldwide. BRUVs have several advantages over many other methods of sampling fish communities, in that is efficient, non-destructive, and less species- and size-selective. The video footage becomes a permanent record of the habitat and biological community.



The BRUV unit comprises a metal frame, two video cameras in special housings, lights, and a long arm with a bait cannister.


The team at Sea Through Science have extensive experience with using underwater video methods across the world, including the Galapagos Islands1,2, New Caledonia, Fiji, Tonga, Rangitāhua/Kermadec Islands, the Poor Knights and Mokohinau Islands, all over the Hauraki Gulf3,4, and Fiordland. Adam co-authored the guide to the BRUV method5 and publications in Nature6 and Science7 as part of the Global FinPrint project.
